713329f.title: Manhattan: 48th Street (West) - 5th Avenue
713329f.text:
19 West 48th Street, north side, west of Fifth Avenue. This building is the home of the Green Room Club.
About 1924.
White Studio.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.

713332f-a.title: Manhattan: 48th Street (West) - 5th Avenue
713332f-a.text:
(1)
West 48th Street, north side, west from Fifth to Sixth Aves. Shown is the parking lot at the rear of the new R.K.O. (Center) Theatre.
between 48th and 49th (also shown on the right) Streets.
May 15, 1933.
. L. Sperr.
(2)
A view mainly of the new theatre, which was known for awhile as
"Roxys"; to-day (1937) being "The Center'.
y
May 15, 1933.
AS'
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same, at an earlier date. (4est 48th Street is the thoroughfare on the left), before the new buildings appearing in view No. 1 were erected. The cleared areas are part of the Euckefeller Center development, shown in completed form in views 1 and 2. Also shown is a portion of the Sixth Ave. Elevated and its 50th Street station, as well as an extended
view of the neighboring area in a westerly direction.
July 11, 1931.
Sperr.  9& MFabUocitows.

723025f-a.title: Manhattan: 5th Street (West) - 48th Street (West)
723025f-a.text:
Sixth Ave., east side, north from and including West 48th to and including West 51st Streets, showing Rockefeller Center (Radio City). In the right foreground is seen the Center Theatre (was temporarily called Roxy Theatre) at the S.E. corner of West 49th Street. North of it is the smaller unit (16-stories) of the R.C.A. Building from West 49th to West 50th Streets; the 70-story R.C.A. structure appearing slightly eastward and facing on Rockefeller Plaza. In silhouette is visible the 31-story R.E.0. Building, from West 50th to West 51st Streets.
1933.
Wurt Brothers.

713330f-b.title: Manhattan: 48th Street (West) - 5th Avenue
713330f-b.text:
(1)
West 48th Street, north side, between Fifth and Sixth Aves., as: viewed from 580 Fifth Ave. Also shown are the rears of Nos. 5-14 West 49th Street. To-day (1937) these are all that remain; the others having been demolished recently and the site occupied by a 45-story office
building.
July 11, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, 1 year later. Note already the nearly completed R.K.O. Theatre Buildinty lat the western end of the parking lot. Skeletal frame work shown will evolve into the 70-story R.C.A. Building.
June 8, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same as No. 2, but more inclusive, and showing a further view
westward.
June 5, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

713331f-a.title: Manhattan: 48th Street (West) - 5th Avenue
713331f-a.text:
ockefeller Center, New Tork  Por more than four decades, the elegant
(ebrruarg 12, 1975  ainbow Room and Rainbow Grill located 65
floors above amidtown.
Manbattan in Sockefellsr Center have been New York City's most talked about restaurant and nighcIi9-th outstappd]ng entertainment and top cuisine plus an
Unexcelled view of the Mhnhattan skyliie.
Cpened to the public as a formal skyscraper supper club in 1334, the 'ainbow Room, above two stories in height, occupies the entire eastern end of the RCA Juildings 65h Hloor. Its 24 floor-to-ceiling windows ine the north and south sides of the spacious dining room permitting breathtaking views of Manhattan island and surrounding areas for 50 miles. Panels between the windows are covered with plum colored silk tafetta, cosplimented by gold draperies and emerald green carpeting. Ihe tables are set on three levels
beneath a magnificent crystal chandelier of classic design.
Cocktails and dinjing arw offered nightly, seven days a week. drunch is
served from 11:30 a.m. to 3 p.m. Saturday and Sunday.
V2726

713327f-a.title: Manhattan: 48th Street (West) - 5th Avenue
713327f-a.text:
12-16 West 48th Street, south side, west of Fifth Avenue.
About 1911.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.

713328f-a.title: Manhattan: 48th Street (West) - 5th Avenue
713328f-a.text:
16-72 West 48th Street, south side, west from Fifth to Sixth Aves., showing prominently the newly erected Winston Building, that will be known as No. 22. The 1934 R.E. Atlas gives the same as the National Jewel's Board of Trade. According to the N.Y. Times of October 31, 1937 the 2 structures (No. 18 and 20), adjacent to the east side of the aforementioned building, will be demolished and their site utilized for a 2-story building to be occupied by B. Westermann Co. No. 18 is the old Rhinelander home and appears on the left. For further data upon same,
see the periodical mentioned.
1928.
Peyser and Patzig.

713326f-a.title: Manhattan: 48th Street - 5th Avenue
713326f-a.text:
48th Street, west from but not including Fifth Avenue. This view shows the street before big business lofts were started there.
1925.
